snippet: In a New York Times/CBS News poll, Catholics said that while their parish priests were in touch with their needs, the church and most American bishops were not.
abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that the Roman Catholic church hierarchy has lost the confidence and allegiance of many American Catholics; seven out of 10 say Pope Benedict XVI and Vatican have done poor job of handling sexual abuse; many believe that church and bishops are out of touch, and that the next pope should lead church in more modern direction on issues like birth control and ordaining women and married men as priests.

byline.original: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN
byline.contributor: Allison Kopicki, Dalia Sussman and Marina Stefan contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: In a New York Times/CBS News poll, Catholics said that while their parish priests were in touch with their needs, the church and most American bishops were not.

headline.seo: Poll Shows Disconnect Between U.S. Catholics and Church
headline.main: U.S. Catholics in Poll See a Church Out of Touch
headline.print_headline: U.S. Catholics in Poll See a Church Out of Touch
